doc.field: Chancellor and municipalities don't agree on savings package

The controversy between the government and the municipalities over the effects of the savings package continues. A meeting between Chancellor Schroeder and the representatives of local central organizations in Bonn ended without concrete results. The municipalities accuse the government of saving at their expense. The chancellor, nevertheless, was uncompromising. Minister of Finance Eichel, who also participated in the discussion, assured only to submit exact calculations over the effects of his savings package. Mr Eichel thinks that the cities and municipalities will not only be burdened, but also relieved. The President of the City and Districts Organization Tallmeier affirmed after the meeting that he strictly rejects a shift of the burden to cities and municipalities. The municipalities are afraid of being burdened by the planned modification of rent subsidy, the rise of child benefits and modification of unemployment relief with about three to four billion DM. The 30 billion DM designated by Eichel would have to be saved alone on federal level, so the demand of the local central associations. Negotiations will continue after the summer break.

Federal Minister of Economics Mueller requested from the Green Party to be willing to make a compromise in the controversy over nuclear power. He told the "Hamburger Abendblatt" that the nuclear power plant operators were ready to give up positions and rights. The Greens and sections of the SPD faction should now consider this movement. Otherwise no agreement would be possible, said Mueller. Main point at issue is the remaining operating time of the nuclear power plants.

The removal of the export ban for British beef continues to be criticized by German politicians. They require above all the application of a 'Quick Test' to detect the cattle epidemic BSE. Great Britain should be obligated to provide such a test, requested Bavarian Health Minister Stamm. The Federal Institute for health consumer protection in Berlin, on the other hand, declared BSE quick tests as meaningless.

A scandal in the district Upper Bavaria keeps the public prosecutor's office busy. The investigators are investigating in connection with foreign travel and premium payments. According to Senior Public Prosecutor Wyk the office is accused of breach of trust. First witnesses were already heard. In question are the foreign travels of CSU District President Filser and other district advisers.

Physicians are in the opinion of the regional court Itzehoe only human and may make errors without being accountable immediately. With this reason the court rejected a damage suit of a patient whose blister closing muscle was hurt during a prostate operation. The court's decision said that even the most experienced and most rested surgeon cannot pay absolute attention during each second of a long operation. Otherwise, one would request something inhuman of a physician.

Due to a large number of orders at BMW the company arranged additional shifts and canceled the factory vacation in Munich and Regensburg. Workers in these two locations will have to work during the month of August. Until the end of the year, BMW wants to create 1,000 new positions. The demand for the 3-Series is particularly large.

Ticket sales began for the Olympic Games 2000 in Sydney. The approximately 50,000 tickets can be ordered in writing at a Frankfurt travel agency. The price for the cheapest ticket is DM 23, the most expensive one costs DM 1,700. The agency also offers several all-inclusive packages. 16 days in Australia cost the Olympics fan approximately DM 6,100, a one-month trip costs DM 23,000.
